titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Buckminster Fuller's World Game: archive of original graphic art, film, video and audio media, manuscript material, and correspondence, from the files of Herbert and Mercedes Matter, ca. 1965-1980
Matter (Herbert and Mercedes), World Game Archive

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Buckminster Fuller's World Game: archive of original graphic art, film, video and audio media, manuscript material, and correspondence, from the files of Herbert and Mercedes Matter, ca. 1965-1980

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

did.abstract: An archive consisting of approximately 500 items from Herbert and Mercedes Matter, including production files and original artwork, manuscript material, correspondence, film and magnetic media, photographs, books, and printed matter.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least 24 hours in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Copyright in papers created by Herbert and Mercedes Matter is held by the Matter estate and shall be administered by their designee. Copyright in other papers in the collection may be held by their authors, or the authors' heirs or assigns. Researchers must obtain the written permission of the holder(s) of copyright and the Head of Special Collections before publishing quotations from materials in the collection.Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Buckminster Fuller's World Game: archive of original graphic art, film, video and audio media, manuscript material, and correspondence, from the files of Herbert and Mercedes Matter, ca. 1965-1980, M1378. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was purchased by Stanford University, Special Collections in 2003. Accession number: 2003-128

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: R. Buckminster Fuller conceived the World Game as an interactive role-playing experience that would teach participants to organize, revitalize and distribute depleted world resources. Relying on computers to provide raw data, players work non-competitively to allocate the earth?s natural capital worldwide, scoring points through efficient management. If cooperation degenerates into competition, the first step towards war, the game is lost. This archive documents the preparations for and execution of the inaugural World Game at the New York Studio School in 1969, which became a prototypical rehearsal for its 1971 appearance at the University of Southern Illinois. Born in Engelberg, Switzerland, Herbert Matter is best known for his international contributions in photography, photomontage, and graphic design work. Matter was also a filmmaker, exhibition designer, and professor. He came to the United States in 1936 and began work as a freelance photographer for Harper's Bazaar and Vogue magazines and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and created displays for the Swiss and Corning Glass Pavilions for the 1939 World's Fair. He also directed, filmed, and edited Works of Calder in 1950 for the Museum of Modern Art, the first color film to show Alexander Calder's sculptures. While maintaining countless assignments, he introduced the first photography classes offered at Yale University where he taught until 1976. In 1943, Herbert married Mercedes de Cordoba and in 1964 she founded the New York Studio School of Painting and Sculpture (the Studio School). When the 1967 Montreal World?s Fair rejected R. Buckminster Fuller?s proposal to have the World Game played at the fair, Herbert and Mercedes offered to host him at the Studio School and offered the school?s student population for the inaugural World Game. Other related collections at Stanford University researchers should investigate would be the R. Buckminster Fuller papers (M1090) and the Herbert Matter papers (M1446).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, photographs, artwork, videotapes, and publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folder numbers consist of the "box number.folder number", e.g. "1.12." The collection is arranged in eight series:

Series I. Administrative Series II. Materials pertaining to the World Game class Series III. Promotional materials Series IV. H. Matter?s film on the World Game Series V. Photographs and negatives Series VI. Artwork Series VII. Publications and books Series VIII. Media

did.unittitle: Series 1:Administrative

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials the Matters collected pertaining to the administrative parts of the World Game class and the creation of a movie based on the class. The correspondence files contain letters from the Matters to R. Buckminster Fuller and from others to the Matters seeking more information on the World Game. A highlight would include the Matters' write up for Fuller's nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize. The series also contains biographical information on Fuller, budgets and receipts, and legal documents including the picture rights agreement between Herbert Matter and Fuller and a fundraising plan for the movie.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, 1968-1980
Correspondence from others
Biographical information on Fuller
Fuller Town Hall, New York, New York, Feb. 26, March 5 and March 12, 1971
World Game budget and expenses
Invoices and receipts for film
Draft regarding fundraising for World Game film
Matter contract with Fuller
Series 2: Materials pertaining to the World Game Class

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents pertaining to the preparations for and execution of the inaugural World Game in 1969. Documents include class roster, suggested reading list, the Matters brainstorming notes, transparencies.

did.unittitle: Class information -- roster, reading list
Draft: agenda and schedule of World Game by Ed Schlossberg
Notes regarding the dynamics of playing the World Game
World Game Report -final and drafts
Unknown manuscript fragment -- could be RBF, "World Game how it came about"
Brainstorming notes
Transparencies used for World Game class
Series 3: Promotional materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Promotional and press materials for Fuller's World Game and internal documents Mercedes Matter created for the New York Studio School. Also included are notes and drafts of articles for publication in magazines specifically the Game and more broadly the scope of Fuller's work.

did.unittitle: Miscelleanous notes, drafts of articles, press releases, promotional brochures
Handwritten drafts and notes for World Game article in newsletter
Layout for Ed Schlossberg's article
Typed report: "How to make the world work: a unique educational experience"
Drafts of New York Studio School's involvement in World Game
Drafts of July 1969 press release
Various drafts of typed paper entitled "World Game" for article in New York school newsletter by M. Matter
Notes and articles by M. Matter, flyers
Advertisement for Fuller's town hall speeches (first proofs)
Miscellaneous posters and mock ups of posters
Poster for town hall speeches, mock up for Alberto Giacometti exhibit, New York, 1974
Series 4: H. Matter's film on the World Game

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains the papers relating to Herbert Matter's documentation of the World Game which ran from June 12 to July 31, 1969. Records include print out of scripts and a narrative account from Matter on what inspired him to create the film.

did.unittitle: Drafts "The World Game" and "Fuller Concepts Operative World Game"
Drafts by Herbert Matter on motivation behind film
Narrative account of World Game film (draft)

Series 5: Photographs and negatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains various photographs, negatives, transparencies, slides and contact sheets related to Fuller and the World Game.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous negatives
Maps and charts of World Game, negatives (first choice)
Maps and charts, World Game, negatives (second choice)
"Maps to enlarge", black and white photographs and negatives
Contact sheets
Miscellaneous photographs
Oversize photographs
Oversize photographs
Series 6: Artwork

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains Matter's original artwork, collages, sketches, paste-ups, proof sheets, and mechanicals, relating to posters, catalogues, media advertising and exhibition displays for the World Game.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous artwork, drawings and posters
Miscellaneous artwork drawings and posters
Series 7: Publications and books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications from the Matters' reference library. Box 10 contains publications that solely deal with the developments of mankind's voyage to the moon. Box 11 contains publications that highlight Fuller's work and the World Game and box 13 contains various clippings. Various books were removed to the Rare Books division and catalogued individually.
